elements.title: sword-billed hummingbird (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the sword-billed hummingbird (example pictured) is the only bird with a bill longer than its body?

elements.title: Noa Denmon (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Noa Denmon's illustration for the Google Doodle on Martin Luther King Jr. Day included people painting a mural while socially distanced due to the COVID-19 pandemic?

elements.title: first circle of hell (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Dante "may have detested everything about Arabs and Muslims", but placed Saladin, Avicenna, and Averroes among the virtuous in the first circle of hell?

elements.title: Ruth Crosby Noble (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that zoologist Ruth Crosby Noble's 1945 book on animal behavior was said to have the "rare quality of combining entertainment with sound scientific value"?

elements.title: Suburbia (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the board game Suburbia is said to be a "masterfully designed game" with "tedious bookkeeping"?

elements.title: Thomas Lüscher (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that according to Swiss cardiologist Thomas Lüscher, chocolate is good for us if it is dark and bitter, but white chocolate is "not healthy at all"?

elements.title: Kimball Island (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that in 2000, the Sacramento County Policy Planning Commission decided that humans would never be allowed to live on Kimball Island again?

elements.title: Charles Allan Marris (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that in The Arraignment of Paris, poet Denis Glover stated Charles Allan Marris was the "arbiter of all our art and letters / presenting rotten apples to his betters"?
